I had to pay for the trip there because I was not working for them. If you have to take trains into London or park in London for this you will understand why this is a problem. The room I had to work in was cold, I could wear my own clothing but for some reason not a fleece or jumper. This was in winter and the room was cold. When I worked for them during the day I found people there helpful. Despite having to get up early I would have liked to remain on the day shift, in hindsight, and received more training. They put me on the nightshift after a month there. This month was broken up by Christmas and new year holidays and a lack of work before the holidays. Then I was put on the night shift. I had agreed to this but needed to have had longer on the day shift to learn how to do my job. Instead of leaving me to work out how to use a piece of equipment on my own, having been shown I just needed to get my head round it, my supervisor decided I was struggling. I got the impression they were picking on everything I did, either they wanted someone they could not get, or they had no clue on how to train people, or both. Also, the e-forms were not user friendly and there were people there who admitted to this. When they decided to get rid of me I was taken into the manager's office and asked what I thought had gone wrong in what seemed to me at the time a patronising manner. review_title: HR departments are the pits of bureaucracy
pros: Other than The HR department everything is good
cons:
HR departments are the pits of bureaucracy 

HR departments are formally responsible for providing professional advice, support and guidance to staff in line with employment legislation and best practice.
 Their role is in essence to ensure that an organization achieves its long-term objectives by helping it to attract, recruit, retain and reward the best talent.
 However, in our experience, they more often act as a hindrance/ dictator with a mindset that engineering department needs to justify their purpose to HR,
 rather than the other way around. Even though the engineering orgs are generating the revenue to pay their salary check

For instance, can you assume that HR will assist with advertising a post, arranging an interview or seeking references: this will invariably be “devolved” or “outsourced” to you or to the third party recruiters. Only once you succeed in recruiting a suitable candidate does HR move in – to bury them in bureaucracy.
